Bug Description:

Bug Title: Incorrect Scope Depth Causing AssertionFailedError

Bug ID: 168, 
Project: Closure, 
Bug Type: SL SH SF (Single Line, Single Hunk, Single File)

Error Message: junit.framework.AssertionFailedError: expected a warning

Bug Details:

The bug in the code lies within the if condition where the scope depth is checked. If the scope depth is less than or equal to 2, the function returns.

Buggy Code:

    if (t.getScopeDepth() <= 2) {
        return;
    }

This condition lead to an AssertionFailedError, as a warning was expected but was not thrown.

In our case, the check for scope depth is presumably incorrect. The code return prematurely, skipping the necessary checks and operations meant to occur beyond this point. This inappropriate return statement led to the junit.framework.AssertionFailedError as the function did not work as expected. 

Solution:

The fix here is to change the value checked in the if condition to 1, indicating that the code should only return if the scope depth is less than or equal to 1.

Fixed Code:

    if (t.getScopeDepth() <= 1) {
        return;
    }

This fix allows the code to continue its execution if the scope depth is greater than 1, avoiding the premature return and enabling it to proceed with the necessary checks and operations. As a result, the warning that was expected by the test case is now being hit, resolving the AssertionFailedError. 

This means that the entire operation is now completed as expected without any premature return of control, thus the fixed code passes the test by raising the expected warning.
